Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. J. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. J. Bruton)
Speaker.P: I am satisfied that where legislation requires that reports from State and semi-State bodies under my aegis are required to be presented to the Oireachtas, publication does not take place until this requirement has been complied with. As the Deputy is aware, the presentation process involves placing copies of such reports in the Oireachtas Library. This is normally reported in the Order Paper for the next day on which the Dáil sits, for the information of Deputies.

MainHeading.P: However, I appreciate that there can be a delay between the time of presentation and the reference thereto in the subsequent Order Paper when, for example, presentation takes place on a Thursday or Friday during a Dáil session or during the recess. In such cases, the reports will have been released publicly during these periods. In my capacity as Leader of the House, I will see if this situation can be improved. While I would be anxious to speed up the flow of information to Deputies, I am also concerned that undue restrictions or difficult requirements should not be placed on the bodies in question.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Grant and Mortgage Subsidy Payments.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment when a person (details supplied) in County Monaghan will receive payment of a £1,000 grant and a mortgage subsidy.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: A grant will be paid when an inspection establishes that the house is completed and occupied and that all the conditions applying to the grant scheme have been complied with. The applicant was not at home when an inspector called recently and, a further inspection, by appointment will be carried out as soon as possible. Payment of the first instalment of the mortgage subsidy cannot be made until the grant has been paid and the applicant submits the relevant claim form, duly certified.

asked the Minister for the Environment the reason a house improvement grant was not granted to a person (details supplied) in County Limerick; when this will be paid; and the amount which will be paid.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: This application was rejected because, contrary to a statutory condition of the scheme, the work had commenced before an inspection of the house was carried out. The applicant has been so informed.

asked the Minister for the Environment the reason a house improvement grant has not yet been paid to a person (details supplied) in County Tipperary; when this will be paid; and the amount which will be paid.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: As my Department has not yet been notified of the completion of the works, to which the grants of £1,200 approved relate, the question of payment has not arisen.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the proposals that both he and his Department have in conjunction with Galway County Council for the upgrading and improvement of the water supply to Tuam town, County Galway; and if he is aware that the people of Tuam have been the victims of a bad water supply for a long period of time; if he will make an immediate decision to direct both his Department and Galway County Council to put the necessary funds and resources into improving the Tuam water supply; the amount of money that will be made available; the exact proposals that will be implemented and if he will make a statement on this serious situation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: It is a matter for each local sanitary authority to determine the water supply needs within its functional area and to submit proposals to meet these needs for my approval. A preliminary report for the proposed Tuam regional water supply scheme was received in my Department on 5 March 1985. Further information was requested from Galway County Council before the report could be considered. This information was received on 29 May 1985 and the report is at present being examined in my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Maintenance of Water Service-Pipes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he intends introducing legislation to end the discrimination against Dublin householders who are held responsible for burst water service-pipes on public thoroughfares outside their homes to which they have in no way contributed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: Dublin Corporation, Dún Laoghaire Corporation, and Cork Corporation are empowered under special Acts to assume responsibility for maintenance of branch pipes which are within their own functional areas. I am having the legislation governing this matter examined with a view to formulating proposals for any necessary extension of these powers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will reconsider his decision not to pay a house improvement grant to a person (details supplied) in County Dublin in view of the urgent need to commence work on the construction of a kitchen and bathroom and the hardship experienced in this case.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: A grant cannot be allowed in this instance because, contrary to a statutory condition of the scheme, the work had commenced before an inspection of the house was carried out.
asked the Minister for the Environment if he proposes to make a supplementary grant available to the Creevalea group water scheme; and when he will make a decision on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: The group's request for a special contribution to enable the scheme to proceed is under examination in my Department and I expect to make a decision in the matter shortly.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - State and Semi-State Bodies Reports.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will take steps to ensure that reports from State and semi-State bodies under the aegis of his Department are made available to Oireachtas Members at the earliest opportunity rather than the present practice which means that Oireachtas Members may get such data many days after these reports have been publicly discussed and circulated; and if he will make the necessary representations to the bodies concerned.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I am satisfied that where legislation so requires reports of bodies under the aegis of my Department are laid before each House of the Oireachtas. If the Deputy is aware of any difficulties in relation to the availability of reports furnished by any of the bodies under the aegis of my Department I would be glad to look into the matter further on receipt of the necessary details.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Income Limits for SDA Loans.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will consider increasing the income levels of £8,000 for qualification for corporation loans as these have not been extended for a number of years.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: The income limit for local authority house purchase and improvement loans was increased to £8,000 with effect from 1 February 1984. While I am keeping this limit under review I am not at present in a position to say when it will be next increased.

asked the Minister for the Environment if he is aware of the hardship being caused to residents of houses in the Infirmary Road area of Dublin who live in what are known as artisans' dwellings which were bought over by Folio Houses Limited some time ago with the result that rents increased dramatically for many long time residents, some of them very elderly; and if he will outline how the Government can help in this matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I have no functions in regard to the level of rents of these houses as fixed by the District Court or the Rent Tribunal. In so far as possible hardship is concerned, there is provision in section 23 of the Housing (Private Rented Dwellings) Act, 1982 for allowances for tenants affected by the decontrol of rents affected by that Act. The administration of this system of allowances is a matter for the Minister for Social Welfare. Section 5 of the Finance Act, 1982, as amended, provides for income tax relief in respect of rents paid in respect of private rented accommodation by tenants aged 55 or over.

asked the Minister for the Environment the total cost of recent Government advertisements on the land tax in the local and national papers; and whether a supplementary estimate will be introduced to cover this cost.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: Information concerning the total cost of recent Government advertisements on farm tax in the local and national papers is not yet available. It is not however envisaged that a Supplementary Estimate will be required in respect of the cost.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Public Service if in relation to the clerical assistant-typist competition, he will indicate the number who were unsuccessful to date out of those placed in the examination.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Public Service (Mr. Boland) John Boland
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Public Service (Mr. Boland)
Speaker.P: It is assumed that the question refers to the most recent clerical assistant-typist competition which was held in November 1984. Of those candidates who passed the typing test in this competition the top 149 candidates have so far been called to the next stages of the competition. Seventy seven (77) of these have completed all stages to date and of these six have been unsuccessful.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - State and Semi-State Bodies Reports.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he will take steps to ensure that reports from State and semi-State bodies under the aegis of his Department are made available to Oireachtas Members at the earliest opportunity rather than the present practice which means that Oireachtas Members may get such data many days after these reports have been publicly discussed and circulated; and if he will make the necessary representations to the bodies concerned.

asked the Minister for the Gaeltacht if he will take steps to ensure that reports from State and semi-State bodies under the aegis of his Department are made available to Oireachtas Members at the earliest opportunity rather than the present practice which means that Oireachtas Members may get such data many days after these reports have been publicly discussed and circulated; and if he will make the necessary representations to the bodies concerned.

Speaker.hpid: Aire na Gaeltachta (Mr. O'Toole) Aire na Gaeltachta (Mr. O'Toole)
Speaker.P: Leagtar tuarascálacha agus cuntais na n-eagras Stát-tionscanta atá faoi scáth mo Roinne faoi bhráid gach Tí den Oireachtas go hanluath tar éis iad a bheith faighte ó na heagrais agus curtha faoi bhráid an Rialtais.

asked the Minister for Communications if he will take steps to ensure that reports from State and semi-State bodies under the aegis of his Department are made available to Oireachtas Members at the earliest opportunity rather than the present practice which means that Oireachtas Members may get such data many days after these reports have been publicly discussed and circulated; and if he will make the necessary representations to the bodies concerned.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Communications (Mr. Mitchell) Jim Mitchell
Speaker.P: All reports from State and semi-State bodies under my aegis which I am required to submit to the Houses of the Oireachtas are presented either prior to or on the same date as they are released to the public. The presentation to the Houses of the Oireachtas of other reports which may be produced or commissioned by such bodies for their own use is a matter of day-to-day administration in which I would not wish to intervene.

asked the Minister for Finance if he will take steps to ensure that reports from State and semi-State bodies under the aegis of his Department are made available to Oireachtas Members at the earliest opportunity rather than the present practice which means that Oireachtas Members may get such data many days after these reports have been publicly discussed and circulated; and if he will make the necessary representations to the bodies concerned.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: The annual reports of State bodies under the aegis of my Department are laid before, or presented to, each House of the Oireachtas at the earliest opportunity. Other reports of those bodies, if published, are made available to Members of the Oireachtas when they are published. It is my intention that this practice will continue to be followed.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Disabled Drivers' VAT Exemption.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if he will extend the provisions for disabled drivers whereby VAT exemptions apply on petrol to ambulances operated by voluntary groups such as St. John's Ambulance when they convey disabled persons.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: The question of extending the petrol duty repayment scheme for disabled drivers on the lines suggested by the Deputy has been examined before. However, it was found that such an extended scheme would be virtually impossible to control properly without the risk of grave loss to the revenue. In any event, I am not disposed to consider any extention of the present scheme pending the outcome of the review of all aspects of transport for disabled people proposed in the Green Paper on services for disabled people, Towards a Full Life.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance when work will commence on the proposed new national school at Drumkeen, County Donegal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: The planning of the proposed new school at Drumkeen, County Donegal, is in the hands of an architect in private practice who has been engaged by the manager. The manager's architect is well advanced on the working drawings and he has been asked to make a number of necessary revisions.

When the working drawings are submitted and found to be in order the Office of Public Works will authorise the preparation of bills of quantities. It is not possible to say at this stage when building work will commence.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Conference Chamber at Dublin Castle.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Brady Mr. G. Brady
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance the plans which his Department has for any proposed demolition of or alteration to any of the structures in the building complex of Dublin Castle; and if he proposes to build a conference centre there.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: While a decision has been taken by Government to restore the buildings of the Upper Courtyard of Dublin Castle and to provide a conference chamber at the rear of the former Children's Court area some details of the plans remain to be finalised. When these have been settled an announcement on the matter will be made.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Walsh Mr. J. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if he will have essential repairs carried out to Castlehaven national school, County Cork; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: As the planning of the proposed new school at Castlehaven, County Cork, is at an advanced stage it is necessary to keep repairs to the existing school to the minimum required. However, I will arrange for the school to be inspected at an early date to establish what repairs are essential to keep the building serviceable until the new school is ready.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Residential Accommodation in Schools for Deaf.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health when work will commence on the new residential accommodation at St. Joseph's School for the Deaf in Cabra and at St. Mary's School for the Deaf.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: My Department has approved of the acceptance of tenders in respect of new residential accommodation at St. Joseph's School for the Deaf and at St. Mary's School for the Deaf in Cabra. Work on both projects is expected to commence in the immediate future.
asked the Minister for Health the projects in each health board area which have been funded from the capital budget in the years 1983, 1984 and 1985, and the amount of money allocated to each.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: The number of projects which were funded from the health capital budget in the years 1983, 1984 and 1985 is estimated to be in the region of 400. The money allocated to these projects involved up to 3,000 individual payments. The work of categorising these payments by project, by health board and by year would require an inordinate amount of staff time and, because of the large volume of detailed information, would be of limited value. If the Deputy has a particular interest in a specific part of this information, and so indicates his interest to me, I will be pleased to supply him with the information which he requires.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Blood Transfusion Service Board.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will make a statement as to the present position in the staff negotiations at the Blood Transfusion Service Board.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: As the Deputy will be aware there are a number of grades of staff employed by the Blood Transfusion Service Board, which are represented by various trade unions and, at any time, a number of issues may be under negotiation. It is not possible, therefore, to make a statement in relation to any specific negotiations which might be in progress. In any event, my general approach is that, as Minister for Health, it is not appropriate for me to make statements about matters which are the subject of negotiation between trade unions and managements of health agencies.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Order of Malta Ambulance Corps.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will provide a grant for the Order of Malta Ambulance Corps to enable them to continue and expand their community work.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: Grants are made to the Order of Malta by the health boards in respect of services provided in their areas. Most of the Order's transport services are provided in the Eastern Health Board area which last year paid grants totalling £48,000 in respect of these services. £20,000 in grants have been paid this year to various branches of the Order of Malta from the special moneys set aside for community services of a social nature provided by voluntary bodies. Applications from some other branches are at present under consideration. A request to provide a grant to meet the costs of replacing three of the Order's ambulances is at present under consideration in my Department.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will make arrangements with the Southern Health Board to ensure that under no circumstances will Caherciveen District Hospital be closed; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: The administration of Caherciveen District Hospital is a matter for the Southern Health Board. I understand from the board that as part of a general review of its budgetary situation the board intended to close a number of beds at the hospital. However, a decision to close these beds has been deferred until after the next meeting of the Southern Health Board which is scheduled for Monday, 15 July 1985.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Galway Hospital Operating Theatre.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the date on which the Western Health Board requested funding from his Department for the new orthopaedic operating theatre at Merlin Park Hospital; and when funding will be provided.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: The Western Health Board requested approval from my Department for the provision of a new operating theatre suite at Merlin Park Regional Hospital on 11 May 1978. Approval in principle was conveyed in November of that year and planning of the project proceeded through its several stages subsequently. I intend that funds will be made available to enable this project to be undertaken during the currency of the national plan. However, the limited capital funds available and the large number of high priority projects for which funds are required make if impossible at this stage to give precise timing for when funding will be available for this project.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Hospital Projects.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the new hospitals and the new extensions to hospitals proposed in the document Building on Reality, 1985-87 and when it is proposed to commence each project.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: The general hospital projects which are specifically mentioned in the document Building on Reality, 1985-87 are: Ardkeen Regional Hospital, Waterford; James Connolly Memorial Hospital, Blanchardstown, Dublin; Castlebar General Hospital; Kilkenny General Hospital; Mullingar General Hospital; Naas General Hospital; Sligo General Hospital; Tallaght Hospital, Dublin; Wexford General Hospital; Mater Hospital, Dublin; St. James's Hospital, Dublin; Cavan General Hospital.

MainHeading.P: Tallaght and Cavan projects involve the building of a new hospital on a new site. Ardkeen involves building a new hospital on the existing hospital site. In every other case the project involves a major development on the existing hospital site and using existing buildings where appropriate.

Construction work is now in progress on the hospitals at Cavan, Mullingar, St. James's and the Mater. The timing for commencement of work on the other hospitals will depend on completion of the various stages of planning and on the availability of capital funds.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he has instructed the health boards to reduce the salaries of student nurses; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: I have not instructed health boards to reduce the salaries of student nurses. I am reviewing the implications of the position which has arisen in certain nurses' training schools regarding payments to students during the introductory period of training.

asked the Minister for Health if he will outline Government policy with regard to the rationalisation of hospitals in the Dublin north city area, referring to the time scale involved and the nature of the consultation with the authorities involved; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: It is Government policy, that following rationalisation measures, the Dublin north city area will be serviced by three major acute general hospitals, namely, Beaumont, James Connolly Memorial and the Mater Hospitals. Consultations are being held with the relevant authorities as the need arises, having regard to the various planning and development stages, the necessity to maintain services and the desire to arrange for the transfer of services as smoothly as possible. The hospital rationalisation and development programme for the Dublin north city area is an ongoing process and is scheduled to be completed by the late 1990s.

asked the Minister for Health if he will consider granting a refund to a person (details supplied) in County Kilkenny in respect of the cost of an eye test and the purchase of glasses as he is in receipt of a non-contributory old age pension.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: In order to ensure that the budget for the adult ophthalmic services scheme is not exceeded the issue of authorisations for sight testing and the supply of spectacles is rigidly controlled by the South Eastern Health Board. The person in question did not await his turn on the waiting list but had a sight test carried out and purchased spectacles privately, without the authorisation of the health board. Health boards do not normally contribute towards the cost of treatment carried out under a private arrangement. However, when the person's name is reached on the health board waiting list for ophthalmic services consideration will be given to the question of making a contribution towards the expenditure incurred.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Social Welfare Benefits.

asked the Minister for Social Welfare when an invalidity pension will be paid to a person (details supplied) in County Wexford.

asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason a dental account for a person (details supplied) in County Tipperary has not been paid; when this will be paid; and the amount which will be paid as this person seems to have satisfied the requirements for elligibility for this claim.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: One of the qualifying conditions for the receipt of dental benefit requires persons over 23 years of age to have had not less than 156 weeks of insurable employment for which the appropriate contributions were paid before the date of commencement of the treatment. The person concerned claimed dental benefit on 14 March 1985. According to the records of the Department he had a total of 79 weeks of insurable employment up to 5 April 1984. Even if he had further contributions continuously from that date to 14 March 1985 he could not have reached a total of 156 contributions by the latter date. His claim could not, therefore, be approved. Both the claimant and his dentist were notified of the position on 17 April 1985.

asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason a person (details supplied) in County Westmeath was refused unemployment benefit or assistance as she had submitted all relevant evidence needed and required by the appeals officer.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: Entitlement to unemployment benefit is subject to the condition that a claimant is available for employment and to fulfil this condition a claimant must be capable of, available for and genuinely seeking employment.

MainHeading.P: The person concerned claimed unemployment benefit on 11 March 1985 but her claim was disallowed on the grounds that by reason of not genuinely seeking employment she was not available for employment. She appealed against the disallowance and attended an oral hearing of her case on 31 May 1985. The appeals officer also decided that she was not available for employment and she was notified of his decision on 6 June 1985. Her entitlement to unemployment benefit from 1 June 1985 is at present under review. She will be informed of the outcome of this review when it is completed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reasons unemployment assistance has been terminated in the case of a person (details supplied) in County Galway; if he is now prepared to reconsider this situation and direct his Department to restore the assistance to this person who is under severe financial pressure; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The unemployment assistance claim of the person concerned was disallowed on the grounds that his means derived from profit from his holding exceeded the statutory limit. He appealed against the disallowance but an appeals officer also assessed him with means in excess of the statutory limit. He was notified of the decision of the appeals officer and ceased to sign as unemployed from 2 April 1985. If the circumstances on which his means were assessed have changed it is open to him to apply for a reinvestigation of his case. A form for this purpose can be obtained at his local office.
asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason unemployment benefit has not been paid retrospectively to a person (details supplied) in County Kildare.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The person concerned attended her local office on 30 April 1985 and applied to sign as unemployed for unemployment benefit purposes from 24 October 1981 to 29 April 1985.

MainHeading.P: Following an examination of her case her application was rejected on the grounds that she was in receipt of disability benefit from 24 October 1981 to 20 May 1982 and maternity allowance from 7 March 1983 to 28 May 1983 and that during the remaining periods she did not show good cause for her failure as a postal applicant to furnish evidence of unemployment by signing as unemployed and furnishing certificates of unemployment. She does not satisfy the contribution conditions for entitlement to unemployment benefit from 30 April 1985.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare when a person (details supplied) in County Clare will be paid his full old age pension.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)

In the light of the information furnished by the Deputy further inquiries are now being made in this case and on their completion the pensioner's entitlement will be reviewed and he will be notified of the outcome.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason unemployment assistance has been reduced in the case of a person (details supplied) in County Galway; if he will direct his Department to restore the amount of payment to its former figure; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

He has not appealed against the amount of means assessed against him and it is open to him to do so. A form for this purpose can be obtained at his local employment office.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Fahey Mr. J. Fahey
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason for the delay in the payment of an invalidity pension to a person (details supplied) in County Waterford.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The person concerned has been awarded an invalidity pension from 4 July 1985. Arrangements are being made to have a pension book issued to the designated post office of payment. Arrears in respect of the period from 4 July 1985 less the amount of disability benefit paid since then will be paid by payable order. A claimant must have been incapable of work for a continuous period of not less than one year before he can be transferred to invalidity pension. The person concerned became incapable of work on 2 July 1984. The earliest date from which he could be awarded invalidity pension therefore is 4 July 1985, that is, the Thursay following the completion of one year's incapacity for work.

asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason a person (details supplied) in County Kildare was refused unemployment benefit on the grounds that she was not available for employment when in fact positive evidence to the contrary was provided.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: Entitlement to unemployment benefit is subject to the condition that a claimant must be available for and genuinely seeking work. The person concerned claimed unemployment benefit from 14 November 1984, but her claim was disallowed by a deciding officer on the grounds that she was not available for employment.

MainHeading.P: She appealed against the disallowance but following an oral hearing of her case on 7 March 1985, an appeals officer also decided that she was not available for employment. Both the deciding officer and the appeals officer took account of evidence provided by the person concerned. In the absence of fresh evidence or new facts the decision of an appeals officer is final.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Andrews Mr. D. Andrews
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if he is aware that boys and girls in residential care, even those who go home every Friday and return every Sunday, have no bus or train pass; and the action, if any, he intends taking to ensure that a pass is given to these individuals in care.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The free travel scheme administered by the Department applies to all persons aged 66 years or over, regisstered blind persons aged 18 years and over and to other persons under age 66 years who are in receipt of a qualifying payment in respect of permanent incapacity.

Persons in residential care would not normally be in receipt of a qualifying payment and would not qualify for free travel. Extension of the scheme to cover children in residential accommodation to enable them to travel free at weekends would have significant implications for the scheme and would give rise to considerable increased costs. There are no proposals for such an extension in present circumstances.

asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will arrange to have a grant under the farm modernisation scheme paid to a person (details supplied) in County Kilkenny where the work has been completed, an inspection carried out and the work approved.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Land Registry Staff Recruitment.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will increase the number of staff employed in the Land Registry in view of the deterioration of service as a result of the embargo on Civil Service recruitment; and if he will make an exception regarding recruitment in so far as the Land Registry is concerned in view of the following: (1) in answer to a question in the Oireachtas in December 1984 he stated that the staff in the Land Registry was 14 per cent lower than when the embargo was introduced in 1981 and that the amount of work dealt with was 9 per cent higher than that in 1980; (2) that, unlike the public service in general, the Land Registry is required by law under the Registration of Title Act, 1964, to be self-financing: (3) that there have been two Fees Orders increasing fees, some by substantial amounts, during the last few years, when staff numbers were actually decreasing; (4) that the necessary increase in staff, in that event, need cost the Exchequer nothing; and (5) that the increase in employment would ensure a more effective operation in the Land Registry, be of great benefit to the public and achieve the objective of the 1977 reorganisation in the Land Registry which reduced average delays for ordinary dealings from six to two and a half months.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he is aware of long delays being experienced by the public and their solicitors in dealings with the Land Registry, apparently arising from reduced staff due to the Government's three-in-one embargo; if, in view of the fact that the Land Registry is required by law to be self-financing, he will authorise the recruitment of additional staff to ease the delays; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I propose to take Questions Nos. 75 and 76, together. As I indicated to the House in the context of the debate on the Estimates for my Department no exception is made for the Land Registry from the staffing restrictions on recruitment which apply throughout the public service. This is a matter of Government policy and, while I accept that it must have inevitable consequences in terms of delays in the Registry, there is no question at present of changing the situation.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Illegal Use of Drugs in Prisons.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Fitzgerald Mr. L. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice (a) the number of occasions in the period August 1972 to August 1982 in which illegal or illegally obtained drugs have been discovered in prisons or institutions administered by his Department; (b) the amount and type of drug discovered on each occasion; (c) the general measures taken to prevent the introduction of and use of illegal or illegally obtained drugs within prisons and institutions under the control of his Department and (d) the nature and extent of training, if any, given to prison staff in the area of drug control.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): It would not be possible without an inordinate use of staff time, to compile statistics of the kind requested by the Deputy at (a) and (b) of his question and I am not prepared to deploy staff on such a task at the expense of delay in performing more important and more urgent tasks.

In regard to (c) efforts are made to prevent the introduction of drugs by searching prisoners suspected of having or using drugs and by close supervision of visits. Visits to prisoners suspected of drug involvement are restricted to special visiting boxes where the passing of drugs can be prevented.

With reference to (d), some training in drug identification and control is given to recruits during their induction training and occasionally selected officers are sent for refresher courses with the Garda drug squad. I might add that training generally for prison officers is one of the matters which falls within the terms of reference of the Committee of Inquiry into the Penal System and the committee is expected to report shortly.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Prison Transport Service.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Fitzgerald Mr. L. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice (a) the number of vehicles in use in the prison service and if he will specify the type of vehicle involved and the area where it is in use; (b) the cost of prison service transport in the period August 1972 to August 1982 and the yearly cost; (c) the cost of additional transport and non-prison transport and if he will give details of any or all additional transport, specifying types and cost; (d) if any plans to provide a separate prison service transport system have been made for the immediate future; and if he will make a statement on these matters.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The information required by the Deputy at (a) of his question is as follows.

MainHeading.P: Number of vehicles: 26. Type: Five cars, two vans, 15 minibuses, two landrovers, two trucks. Location: St Patrick's Institution — one minibus, *two cars; Mountjoy Prison — two vans, two minibuses; Portlaoise Prison — one minibus; Limerick Prison — two minibuses; Shanganagh Castle — two minibuses; Cork Prison — one minibus; Loughan House — two minibuses; Shelton Abbey — one minibus, one car; Arbour Hill Prison — one minibus; Training Unit — one minibus, one car; Central Prison Stores — one minibus, one car, two trucks; Fort Mitchel Prison — two landrovers.
*Includes one car on loan from Garda Síochána.
The information required at (b) and (c) of the Deputy's question is not readily available. To compile such information a disproportionate amount of staff time and resources would be involved.

As regards the final part of the Deputy's question there are no plans at present for the introduction of a separate prison service transport system and I am quite satisfied that the existing system is adequate to suit prison needs.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Portlaoise Prison D Block.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Fitzgerald Mr. L. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice (a) whether he considers the area commonly referred to as the D Block in Portlaoise to be suitable for the housing of persons in custody; (b) the number of occupied cells in that block; (c) the total number of prisoners and the average number of prisoners per cell; (d) the dimensions of such cells; (e) the hygiene facilities and the recreational facilities available in this area; (f) the age of the building and whether the building has continuously been used for the accommodation of prisoners; (g) in the event that the building has not been in continuous use for the accommodation of prisoners, the stage at which it was last taken over for such a use and the time gap which existed since it had previously been used for this purpose; (h) if he is aware of any recommendations made by medical authorities in Portlaoise with regard to the suitability of this building for the confinement of those in custody; and if he will make a statement on these matters.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The D Block in Portlaoise Prison, which dates back to the middle of the last century, has 31 cells. Twenty-three are currently in use. There are in the region of 60 non-subversive-type prisoners accommodated there at present. The prison records do not show when the block ceased to be used as accommodation for prisoners or why it ceased to be used. In 1974 it was brought into operation again as accommodation for prisoners. Bearing in mind the age of the building, the block provides reasonable accommodation for the prisoners and it is being further renovated at present. I am not aware that the prison medical officer has made any recommendation regarding the suitability of the block as accommodation for prisoners.
There are nine cells measuring 13 ft. 6 ins. × 8 ft. 6 ins. × 8 ft. 3 ins. high approximately together with 14 cells measuring 9 ft. 10 ins. × 8 ft. 6 ins. × 8 ft. 3 ins. high.

The hygiene facilities are composed of two toilets, two urinals, one sluice, five washhand basins with hot and cold water in each and two shower units. In addition work is nearing completion on the provision of additional facilities as follows: two toilets, two urinals, one sluice, six washhand basins and four showers. Recreational facilities include piped television, video projector for showing of films and pool tables. The prisoners can avail of outdoor exercise each day in an area adjacent to the block if they so wish.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Cost of Prison Projects.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Fitzgerald Mr. L. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice (1) if he will give the cost of the following: (a) the new education unit at Arbour Hill Prison; (b) the construction of a temporary security fence at Arbour Hill Prison; (c) the renovation of the Governor's house at Arbour Hill Prison; (d) the new reception and visiting area at Mountjoy Prison; (e) the new base area in St. Patrick's Institution; (f) the new staff quarters at Loughan House; (g) the new landings and cat walks at Arbour Hill Prison; and (2) the costs involved in preparing Loughan House for its current function of detaining juveniles under the age of 16; the amount of funds expended on structural alterations and improvements since its occupation by such juveniles, excluding the cost of the already mentioned staff quarters; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): Apart from reconstruction of the lower ground level of a wing of St. Patrick's Institution and temporary enclosure of an exercise area in Arbour Hill Prison, the information in my reply has been received from the Office of Public Works, which places most major contracts on behalf of my Department.

It is not the practice to divulge the precise value of individual contracts but substantially accurate approximations of the total cost are given in this reply. Some of these projects extended over a number of years and the cost includes price increases (provided for in the contracts) for materials and wages as well as professional fees and VAT. In instances where final settlement of the account has not been reached, the likely final cost has been estimated.

In several instances the question seeks the cost of only one element of more extensive works done under a contract. It would not be possible, without a lapse of time and incurring professional fees, to extract the information sought. The reply indicates the larger context of work in which these elements occur.

MainHeading.P: 1 (a) The final cost of work done in Arbour Hill Prison, on demolition of old Army dwellings, redevelopment of the cleared site as a secure rear entrance, replacement of the perimeter wall along two sides of custodial precincts, surfacing of exercise yards and construction of a two level building to house education, work-training and production of braille material, is likely to be approximately £1.3 million.

1 (b) Included in that figure is approximately £16,000 for the erection of temporary fencing on a steel framework, to enclose the principal exercise yard and enable it to continue to be used by prisoners while the perimeter was being replaced and the other works outlined were in progress nearby.

1 (c) Renovation of the Governor's House in Arbour Hill was undertaken as part of work related to the security enclosure of the western side of the prison. The work included demolitions, reconstructions, walling of areas in front and at the rear, high secure fencing between custodial precincts and the staff residence, work to the main gate of the prison, construction of staff posts at the entrance area, improvement of access and considerable surfacing. The cost was about £160,000.

1 (d) Construction of a new building fully equipped and furnished for admissions-discharges and visiting commenced in Mountjoy Prison in 1979. Work continued until 1982 and the prison had to be kept operating securely while the work proceeded. Adjoining this building a perimetered exercise yard suitably laid out for outdoor games was provided. Additionally, in this sector of prison precincts, the appropriate part of underground ducts and piping-cabling etc, for all services required when the prison is fully modernised was constructed, the overlying pathways and roadways were laid and surfaced and the new lighting was installed. The work cost approximately £3.2 million.

1 (e) Reconstruction of the lower ground level of a wing of St. Patrick's Institution, to provide a modern separation sector (containing cells, work and association facilities) in half the area and workshop accommodation for the institution generally in the other half, disclosed structural deterioration affecting the entire wing which necessitated consolidation of foundations, replacement of the floor overhead in reinforced concrete and major work to services. The cost was approximately £790,000.
1 (f) The final cost of the staff residence in Loughan House, including related site works, is likely to be approximately £1 million.

1 (g) The final cost of replacing the steel walkways, giving access to cells at upper level throughout Arbour Hill Prison, and of fire resistant floorcovering throughout the prison wings is estimated to be nearly £400,000.

2 The cost of preparing Loughan House as a place of open custody — including site preparation, roadways, water and sewerage services, lighting, major structural adaptation as well as servicing, equipping and furnishing of the original buildings and fencing — was approximately £1.2 million. The final cost of work carried out since then is likely to be about £1.7 million. This work — excluding the staff residence — includes a gymnasium, stores, maintenance workships, a boilerhouse, water and fuel storage, electrical and mechanical emergency installations, roadways, carpark, and (since the place reverted to use for older offenders in May 1983) prefabricated buildings for visiting and work-training.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Fitzgerald Mr. L. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice (a) whether any specific training is given to prison officers in the handling of disturbances in prisons and, if so, if he will give details; (b) if no training or partial training is given, if he intends to introduce or extend such training, and, if so, when and if he will outline the context of this training; (c) the written instructions given to staff in the event of disturbances; (d) if there are instructions to prison officers in the event of a fire alarm in a prison; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): Prison officers are given instruction in the handling of disturbances during their induction training course. They are given further instruction in the course of their normal duties on the steps to be taken in the event of a disturbance or fire occurring in the institution in which they are serving. These instructions may vary from one institution to another depending on the type of institution involved. Practical demonstrations in the use of fire fighting equipment are given periodically. Procedures for handling disturbances are kept under review. For security reasons it would not be appropriate to disclose in greater detail the instructions given to staff in this context. As I have already stated in reply to an earlier question, training generally of prison officers falls within the term of reference of the Committee of Inquiry into the Penal System and the committee is expected to report shortly.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he can assess the effectiveness of the neighbourhood watch pilot scheme in Finglas; if he is satisfied that adequate resources have been allocated to the scheme; the reduction there has been in the number of Garda personnel stationed in the Finglas area; when it is intended to restore the numbers to their original level; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I would refer the Deputy to my reply to Question No. 157 on 2 July 1985 in which I dealt with the overall effectiveness of Neighbourhood Watch. The Garda authorities inform me that it is too early to make a definitive assessment of the neighbourhood watch scheme in Finglas but that, as in other areas, the scheme has had positive effects in terms of crime prevention and detection and better Garda/community co-operation.

As I indicated to the Deputy in my reply to Question No. 729 on 2 May 1984, it is not the practice to allocate a specific proportion of Garda resources in any area to the neighbourhood watch scheme. I am informed by the Garda authorities, however, that they are satisfied that overall Garda resources at Finglas are adequate to cater for the needs of the scheme which is essentially a network of public spirited people who observe what is going on in their own neighbourhood and report suspicious or unusual happenings to the Garda.

As regards Garda strength at Finglas station, the Garda authorities report that the current overall strength assigned there represents a net increase of 19 members over the strength on 31 December 1981 and that the question of replacing two members from the station who were reassigned to other stations in the DMA Northern Division earlier this year is being kept under review.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if any assessment has been made as to the success of the pilot schemes undertaken by this Department in Claremorris, County Mayo, and Thomastown, County Kilkenny regarding the restructuring of the Garda services in these areas; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The operation of the pilot policing scheme in Claremorris and Thomastown Garda districts is at present under review, with a view to establishing whether it meets effectively the objective of improving the level of Garda service in rural areas.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Garda Recruitment.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the reason a candidate (details supplied for the Garda Síochána was rejected on medical grounds despite the fact that he has a specialist's report deeming him fit for duties.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): In accordance with the Garda Síochána (Appointments) Regulations, a candidate cannot be appointed to the force unless the Garda surgeon — or a medical practitioner nominated by the Minister where it is impracticable for the surgeon to examine candidates within a reasonable time — certifies that he is in good health, of sound constitution and fitted physically to perform the duties of a member of the force.

I am informed by the Garda authorities that the person concerned was medically examined by the surgeon on two occasions and the surgeon was unable to certify that the candidate was of the required medical standard. The candidate subsequently submitted a medical report and the matter was reviewed by the surgeon but again he was unable to certify that the candidate was of the required medical standard.

MainHeading.P: I am also informed by the Garda authorities that, if the candidate's condition is treated successfully, he would not be precluded on medical grounds for applying for any future competition for entry to the force for which he is otherwise eligible.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Andrews Mr. D. Andrews
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he is aware that approximately 2,000 men and 500 women were put on a waiting list to be later called to Templemore Garda Training Depot and that a number of these people gave up jobs to join the Garda and they were informed that they would be called in due course, and the action, if any, he intends taking in this matter urgently.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The number of candidates who qualified at the competitive interview in the 1983 Garda Síochána recruitment competition was 1,944 men and 987 women. The interview was conducted by the Civil Service Commission who placed the candidates in order of merit, notified each candidate of his-her placing and informed each one that the Garda Commissioner would write to those candidates who came into the running for appointment.

I am informed by the Garda authorities that a total of 1,195 men and 93 women have todate been called for medical examination and, where appropriate, oral Irish tests. The numbers appointed to date are 774 men and 50 women, and further groups of recruits are due to be appointed in August and October next.

I am also informed by the Garda authorities that any candidate who has not been called for medical examination and who inquired as to his-her prospects of a call-up was informed that the Commissioner was not in a position to indicate the likely number of appointments to the force from the current list or if the candidate was likely to come into the reckoning for a call for medical examination, but that he-she would be informed of developments in that area as soon as possible.

MainHeading.P: A decision has not yet been taken as to precisely how many of those who qualified in 1983 will be offered appointments. This will depend on factors such as the number of vacancies arising and also, of course, on the number of candidates who pass the medical examination and the number who accept an offer of appointment. I might add that I would consider it to be imprudent for any person who qualified to relinquish other employment until he-she has been offered appointment.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Dangerous Substances Regulations.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if, in view of the recent tragedy in Bhopal involving industrial chemicals, he has any plans to update regulations governing the use of industrial chemicals in Ireland.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: My Department is giving priority to the finalisation of draft regulations to implement the EC Council Directive 82/501/EEC of 24 June 1982 on the major accident hazards of certain industrial activities (the Seveso Directive) following consultation with the other Departments concerned and the Dangerous Substances Advisory Council.

MainHeading.P: The directive is concerned with the prevention of major accidents resulting from a range of industrial activities involving the use of dangerous chemicals and with limiting their consequences for man and the environment. The directive imposes duties on manufacturers and on the State. Manufacturers are required to identify major accident hazards, to draw up plans both for the safe operation of the plant and for dealing with any malfunction that might arise and to provide evidence that these requirements have been met. Member states are obliged to set up a competent authority or authorities which will be responsible for receiving and examining this evidence and ensuring that an emergency plan be drawn up for action outside the installations concerned. The directive also requires that persons liable to be affected by a major accident be informed in an appropriate manner of the safety measures and the correct behaviour to adopt in the event of an accident. The proposed regulations, when they come into operation, will supplement the existing legislative measures, namely Dangerous Substances Acts and regulations, which are enforced by my Department and which cover petroleum and other designated dangerous substances.
